text: And this is a controversial exercise.
It's a little dark, I'll admit.
But EpicTidah says, as you kiss your child good night,
whisper to yourself, he may be dead in the morning.
He may be dead in the morning.
That's heavy, right?
But it's important because what that does
is it makes you present.
A few years ago, a friend of mine
is named Seth Roberts.
He sent me an email on a Friday afternoon.
I saw it, I said, I love Seth, but I'm busy.
I'll get to this on Monday.
The next day, he went for a hike,
and he fell dead of a heart attack.
I never got to respond to that.
I never got to talk to him that one last time,
even though he reached out to me.
You're often rushing, right?
You rush through dinner with your spouse.
You rush through your drive home.
You're rushing, rushing, rushing,
got things to do, you got places to be.
But what the Stoics would ask is,
what are you rushing towards?
They would say you're rushing towards death.
You're rushing away from the people you love,
and you're doing it so you can watch more Netflix
or respond to more emails or play apps on your phone.
So when you realize this, you slow down.
You appreciate, you enjoy, you breathe in.
You don't take it for granted.
In light of our mortality, it's arrogant
to blow people off, to ignore them,
to defer to later, to make plans
for the distant future.
It's ridiculous.
